snippet: A seven-year study suggests a higher intake of vitamin D reduces stress fractures in girls 9 to 15.
abstract: Kendrin R Sonneville study published online in Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine finds that higher amounts of vitamin D in the diet are associated with a lower risk for bone fractures in teenage girls.
lead_paragraph: A seven-year study suggests a higher intake of vitamin D reduces stress fractures in girls 9 to 15.

headline.seo: Vitamin D Is Linked to Fewer Bone Fractures in Girls
headline.main: Childhood: Vitamin D Means Fewer Fractures for Girls
headline.print_headline: Childhood: Vitamin D Means Fewer Fractures for Girls
